executive_summary.key_finding: GenAI increases critical thinking by 30.7% when paired with high self-confidence

scenarios.name: GenAI + Self-Confidence Building
scenarios.description: Students use GenAI strategically while maintaining high self-confidence
why_explanation: Students have strong self-confidence in their own problem-solving abilities
GenAI is used strategically to offload repetitive mechanical tasks
Cognitive resources are freed up for higher-order critical thinking
Students critically evaluate and refine AI outputs rather than accepting passively
Creates a synergy effect: confidence + tool = amplified capabilities
key_behaviors: Uses GenAI to check work, not do work
Asks 'why' and 'how' when reviewing AI suggestions
Treats GenAI as a thinking partner, not a replacement for thinking

scenarios.name: Balanced GenAI Use
scenarios.description: Moderate self-confidence with moderate GenAI usage
why_explanation: Students have decent self-confidence in their abilities
GenAI is used moderately, neither avoided nor over-relied upon
Some cognitive offloading occurs, freeing time for thinking
Occasional passive acceptance of AI outputs, but generally evaluative
Results in solid improvement over traditional learning (18.9%)
key_behaviors: Uses GenAI for some tasks, traditional methods for others
Sometimes questions AI outputs, sometimes accepts them
Developing a relationship with AI tools
Still building confidence in both self and tool

scenarios.name: Traditional Classroom (No GenAI)
scenarios.description: No GenAI assistance available, varied self-confidence
why_explanation: No GenAI tools available to offload mechanical tasks
Students spend significant time on repetitive work
Self-confidence varies, but tool availability doesn't amplify it
Critical thinking occurs, but is limited by time spent on mechanics
Represents the traditional learning paradigm we're comparing against
key_behaviors: Completes all work manually, including repetitive tasks
Time spent on mechanical tasks reduces critical thinking time
Relies entirely on own abilities and teacher guidance

scenarios.name: GenAI Over-Reliance
scenarios.description: Low self-confidence with high GenAI dependency
why_explanation: Students lack confidence in their own problem-solving abilities
GenAI becomes a crutch rather than a tool
Passive consumption of AI outputs without critical evaluation
No cognitive engagement with the problem-solving process
Dependency prevents development of critical thinking skills
Students become order-takers from AI rather than independent thinkers
key_behaviors: Immediately turns to GenAI without attempting problems
Copies AI outputs without understanding or evaluation
